Another, my close friend Shariq, only grew to be about twelve feet tall and stayed relatively skinny. But all of us were changed, and we loved it.”

“Amazing,” Peter said. “Do you know why?”

“Well, after realizing that the plant and wildlife in the area were also much bigger than normal, we guessed it had something to do with some force in the area. We didn’t discover exactly why until we explored the cave further, and we found something amazing.”

“What is it?” Peter asked.

“I...I can’t really explain it,” Nikhil said, shaking his head. “It’s something you’ll have to see for yourself. I’ll take you there tomorrow.”

“Okay,” Peter said. Though he really wanted to know more about what was in the cave, he trusted Nikhil to show him when the time was right. “There’s one thing you haven’t told me though. Where are all your friends now?”

Nikhil’s shoulder’s slumped, and he dropped his face. After a short silence, he looked up, with a sad expression on his face, and told Peter what had happened:
131212.title: Nikhil explains it all

choices: A ten foot tall, glowing blue crystal.
A small, humanoid, babylike creature.
1312122.content:
“Dead!” Peter exclaimed. “How in the world did that happen?”

Nikhil sighed. “It was about three months after the crash. We had built this village you see here, and had become excellent hunters and gatherers. Though the thought of rescue or discovery hadn’t left our minds, we were happy and content with our little civilization. And then, the Hunters came.” 
“The Hunters?” Peter asked. “You mean those guys who were chasing us?”

“Yes, they’re few of many.” Nikhil said. “There’s probably about three dozen of them total. They’re men-for-hire, some of them from the surrounding area, some of them flown in from elsewhere. All of them are doing this for only one thing: money.”

“But,” Peter thought for a moment, “ where is the money coming from, then?”

Nikhil reached under the bed and pulled out a sheet of paper. “From him,” he said, as he slid it over to Peter.

Peter quickly recognized the sheet as the front page of an Indian newspaper, and, though it was in Hindi, he understood what Nikhil was referring to. A large picture of a white man with a mustache and dark glasses covered the sheet. Peter guessed he was a general of some sort. “Who is this?” he asked.

“Demidov,” Nikhil responded. “He’s an old Soviet general, who hated capitalism and detested the new Russian government, and left the country after the fall of communism, taking with him about a hundred soldiers as followers.”

“I see,” Peter said, “but why is he here now, trying to kill you?”

Nikhil looked out the window, off into the distance. “Because, once all the guardians are dead, there’s nothing stopping him from getting to the one thing he wants most.”

“And what is that?” Peter asked.

“Come,” Nikhil said as he stood up. As if on cue, Kalima also quickly stood up and walked over next to him. “You need to see it with your own eyes.”

Nikhil reached out his hand, motioning Peter to step on. Peter did so, and Nikhil placed him on his shoulder. Quietly, he left the hut, and walked slowly through the rest of the village. Peter looked around, a knot forming in the pit of his stomach. The deserted village reminded him of ghost towns he visited while vacationing in Colorado as a kid, just at a scale of three to four times larger.

As they neared the other end of the village, Peter saw they were approaching a cave. “Is this...?” he asked. Nikhil simply nodded.
They entered the cave, Kalima going first with Nikhil a few yards behind her. Peter suddenly felt a chill, partly from the drop in temperature, and partly from the dark. Nikhil didn’t have a torch or lantern, but seemed to be able to navigate the passageways in the dark with ease. Peter’s breathing began to quicken. Sensing his fright, Nikhil gave him a soft pat on the pack, and whispered, “Don’t worry, we’re almost there.”

After a few quiet minutes, they arrived at a giant cavern, with a ceiling stretching, at Peter’s best estimate, about 100 feet high. The cavern was filled with an eerie blue glow; Peter was happy just to have some light, though it did look to be a light source unlike any he had seen before.

Kalima was whimpering somewhat, making sure she stayed close to Nikhil’s feet. Nikhil stopped, and turned around to face Peter. “We’re here,” he said.

“Where’s here?” Peter asked. “What is this place?”

“It’s the... well, how do I describe it,” Nikhil said, thinking. “It’s the heart and soul of this area of the jungle. It’s the whole reason we’re in this mess.”

“But why?!” Peter exclaimed, his face getting red. “What makes this cavern so special.”

Nikhil stuck out his hand and pointed a long finer towards the center of the cavern. “That,” he said, simply.

Peter turned towards what Nikhil was pointing at, and it nearly knocked his socks off to see the source of the light, and that it was...
1312122.title: "They are all dead."

choices: A gliding, mysterious, otherworldly figure
One of Demidov's men, holding a pick-ax and chunk of the crystal
13121221.content:
Peter fell backwards a bit in shock when he saw the large, blue crystal at the center of the cavern. It seemed to be fixed in the middle of a rock formation, and had to be nearly ten feet from top to bottom, tapering to a point at both ends. There was an almost unearthly glow to it, and it pulsated at an irregular rhythm, as if trying to slowly signal something.

"What--what the hell is that?" Peter shouted,  turning his head up to Nikhil, who was stoned-faced.

"I don't know exactly what it is or where it came from." The large Indian boy sat down next to Peter, his eyes fixed on the crystal. "I just know it's what has caused everything within twenty or thirty miles of here to become overgrown. It's what made me the way I am."

Peter couldn't believe his ears. "But how-- how could it do that?"

"I'm no expert," Nikhil leaned back, "but I'm guessing that there's something in that crystal that changes the cellular structure of organic life. I mean, it affects every kind of creature living around here: me and my friends, Kalima, the plants and trees..."

"Did you all touch it or something?" 

Nikhil shook his head. "Touching it doesn't do anything unusual. But if you go straight up through the rock formation," he drew a line with his finger from the top of the crystal up through the entire stalactite above it, "you'll end up at the bottom of a large lake, the main source of water for this area of the jungle."

Peter nodded a little, beginning to comprehend, and ran his fingers through his hair. "I guess that would explain why everything grew, even things that had never been down here to the caves. But wait!" His nose scrunched up as Nikhil looked down at him. "If the water has the properties to make you grow, why doesn't Demidov just drink from the lake, and have all his men drink too?"

Nikhil stood up again, starting to pace around the cavern. "He tried that. But apparently, when dissolved in water, the crystal's powers only work on creatures that are still growing, basically children,  teens, cubs, saplings -- that kinda thing. And though it caused us to grow huge and muscular, it stopped our development in other ways -- slowing down our aging process, or at least the appearance of it."

"Ah," Peter realized something, "so that's how you could've come here fifteen years ago and still look like a young teenager. So how old would that make you then?"

Nikhil thought for a second. "I stopped keeping track of that long ago when it looked like it would no longer matter, but I guess I'd be about twenty-eight. I still look and feel like a thirteen-year old though. You know, except for these." He smiled and gave a little flex of the arms, his thick biceps bulging out and his chest muscles swelling slightly. 

"Tch," Peter said, smiling at the impressive display of boy in front of him. "Well at least you're modest about it." He winked at Nikhil, who chuckled and blushed slightly, then turned his attention back to the matter at hand. "So what does Demidov want with the crystal then, if it doesn't make him grow when he touches it or when he drinks from its water?"

Nikhil shrugged. "I don't know. He must have found some other way to tap into its power, maybe even some way that'd be even more effective, possibly turning him into a god. But I do know this: he's an evil man, he wants it, and he'll kill for it. That combination is never good." 

Nodding in agreement, Peter started to look around the cavern, able to just barely make out something on the opposite wall that looked intriguing. Curious, he made his way over to that side, examining the wall closely. It appeared to be markings of some kind, apparently burned onto the wall in an unusual pattern.

"What are these marks?" he called out to Nikhil, who made his way over to look as well. "Did you and your friends make these?"

"No," Nikhil said, shaking his head, "they were he long before we arrived. By the looks of them, I'd say they're ancient, maybe thousands or millions of years old."

"Huh," Peter studied them closer. There were two basic sections to the markings. The first was a large outline of an unusual, almost amorphous shape, longer than it was wide, with six large burn spots inside the lines. The second was a pattern of eight mostly concentric circles surrounding a small dot in the middle. There were two large burn spots on the lines of the third and fifth circles. 

"Do you know what they mean?" Peter asked the larger boy, who had bent over to look at them closer. "Maybe they tell us something about the crystal, or how to defend it."   

Nikhil rubbed his chin as he stared at the markings for a bit longer, finally giving up. "No, I don't think they mean anything. Probably just a caveman playing with a burning stick."

"Maybe," Peter mused. Both patterns looked familiar, as if he'd seen them before, but he couldn't quite place what they were.

Before he could think about it any more, a loud blast sounded behind them. Both boys whirled around, shocked to see the crystal pulsating wildly, blinking off and on rapidly, getting brighter and brighter. After ten or fifteen seconds, the cavern was filled with another loud blasting sound, and a circle of light and wind spread out from the crystal. The wave swept through the cavern, sending Peter flying against the wall when it hit him and even knocking the formidable Nikhil on his butt. 

As both boys recovered and resumed staring in wonder at the crystal, they could make out the silhouette of a figure emerging from the other side of the its glow. Peter brought his hand up to cover his eyes and tried to make out who - or what it was. He was shocked to see --
13121221.title: The Source

choices: Maui and Peter go fishing together
Maui and Peter go for a swim in the lake
132.content:
Peter walked through the jungle, feeling scared, lonely and tired. He was in an unknown place, where he didn’t know the territory or the language. He wasn’t even sure which country he was in. All he knew that he was flying over Africa somewhere when the plane went down. To make matters even worse, the storm was really picking up and the rain was coming down heavier with every passing moment. He was drenched beyond belief as he tried to crawl out of the wreckage of the plane. As he looked on, it was just a miracle that he survived the crash! The trees had stopped the crash, the wings had ripped apart, and luckily he was able to walk away with just a few scrapes and bruises.

Then, he saw something move in the distance. As Peter started to move, his ankle reminded him of the injury. He couldn’t walk. Peter fell down to the floor, and he lay on his back. It was hopeless; he couldn’t move. All he could do now was pray for the best. He was in God’s hands.

There it was. Out of the bushes, a huge figure appeared. It was a man. Or, at least, it was a human being. And it was absolutely humongous! The figure was towering over Peter as it looked down on him. It had a loin cloth over its midsection, but, other than that, its long, muscular legs were very imposing. A thick, wide torso, accentuated by mighty abdominals and bulging pectorals, and then those thick, muscular arms… Peter felt like he was looking up to a large, tanned bodybuilder. Still, the face on top of the large body looked like that of a young boy, and not like that of a grown man.

The boy spoke up in a high-pitch voice, confirming what Peter had thought. He spoke in a strange language, which he didn’t understand. Still, the boy looked to be much taller and bigger than an average adult. He was certainly twice as big as an adult, standing more than a dozen feet tall, and with all that muscle on him, Peter knew that the boy was incredibly strong for sure.

The giant boy looked down on Peter and then, with a smile on his face, he reached down with his huge hands, and he picked Peter up and held him in his arms like he was holding a little infant. Peter felt the powerful, muscular arms and the huge fingers of the mighty hands hold his body in his grip. Still, the giant boy held him in an incredibly lovingly way. The boy somehow looked at him like he was caring for a little baby or a wounded animal, as he slowly started taking Peter away.

The boy then headed deeper and deeper into the jungle, until he came closer to a lake which was surrounded by trees. There, he climbed up a crude ladder, which led up to a tree-house. There, he set Peter down on a large bed made of leaves, before running down again and collecting more leaves from the trees. He quickly returned again, and placed more leaves in order to expand the bed, making it big enough for the two of them. Then he lay down, with Peter next to him.

“Peter!” Peter said, pointing at his chest. “Peter!”

“Maui!” the giant boy replied, while he pointed his giant finger at his huge, bulging chest.

“Okay… Maui…” Peter grinned. At least now he knew what the big boy’s name was.

The huge boy had an oriental expression on his face. He looked like a Pacific Islander with a golden tan and deep, brown eyes. It would be curious to know how this boy ended up over here in Africa? Also, how did the boy end up so big?

As Peter looked down, he noticed that the boy was at least twice as tall and twice as big as him, even more! Peter guessed that the boy was nearly fifteen feet tall and he had a great amount of muscle on him.

But for now, Peter just closed his eyes and drifted off in a deep sleep, as Maui lay right next to him.
132.title: 14-foot tall 10-year-old Hawaiian boy w/ long b...

134.content:
Something tall smashed through the trees. Pete stared up to see a huge figure in front of him. The huge, towering, muscular figure of...a twelve year old boy. Or at least, he looked twelve. If twelve-year-old boys had growth-spurts that sent them up to ten feet in height. The boy wore a simple tunic and robes, and he looked a bit like an ancient Roman. He stared carefully around, as if looking for something. Then he started looking down. Leaves crunched as he got slowly to his knees and brought his head right down to the ground. His hair glowed golden in the sunlight.

"Wheeeere aaaaare you...?"

Despite his gigantic size, Peter guessed the boy was no older than about twelve. Thirteen at the most. He probably wasn't very dangerous, but Pete could tell the boy was built. His arms were thick and firm and he looked like he lifted boulders the size of houses every day!

"Aaah hah!"

Three fingers the size of sausages reached into the hole in the tree-trunk and grabbed Peter around the waist. Peter screamed as the boy hoisted him into the air.

"Wooooow!!" said the boy, holding Peter up in the air, "A little dude!"

"Hey what's the big deal!?"

The boy yelped and dropped Peter, he fell and hit the ground. Fortunately, the grass and leaves broke his fall.

"Wow you can talk!" the boy said.
"Well duh!" Peter said, "Who are you!?"
"WHO ARE YOU!?"
"I'm Peter," said Peter.
"Derek!" said the enormous buff boy.
"Where...where am I?" said Peter.
"It's a jungle! What do you think?" Derek said, "You sure are small for your age".
"You sure are big for yours!" said Peter.

The boy laughed, "I like you, you're funny!"

And Derek grabbed Peter and hoisted the young man up onto his shoulders as if he was a baby. Holding onto the boy's thick neck, Peter sat himself as comfortable as he could on his massive, broad shoulders and held on for the ride!

1413.content:
Tommy was both amazed and terrified by the human, he assumed he was human, in front of him. The individual was a giant about 20 feet tall and very muscular. Shoulders as big as beach balls, biceps bigger than tree trunks, a broad, thick torso, with huge pecs that looked more like two thick granite plates, a powerful 8-pack, legs bigger than anything he had ever seen, but the even more surprising was that his face looked like that of a child, perhaps younger than Tommy himself.

"Who are you?" asked the young giant in a tone of voice that, at the same time, showed youth and power.

"M-my name is To-Tommy, T-t-Tommy H-Hughes." Tommy replied with a mixture of dread and surprise.

"My name is Matthew Fairbanks, but you can call me Matt." The gigantic boy replied, "You should be in bed, the Doctor said you still haven't recovered from the accident." He continued in a critical tone "Come on, I'll take you back." With that, Matt took Tommy, who felt the giant hand wrap his whole body with a certain pressure. Within seconds they reached the room and the giant deposited him on the bed. "Wait here, I'll call the doctor."

"W-wait, where am I?"

"You are at Elysium."

A few minutes after Matt left, he returned with an older man, in his sixties who was a more normal size, about 6ft2.

"Hello my young Tommy, I am Dr. Yanna, I was the one who took care of you when your plane crashed. Mattie warned me of your attempt to escape, that was unwise to do, since you have not yet fully recovered from your accident." Said the man in a tone similar to what a father would use on a disobedient son.

"Sorry, sir, but I was, I am, scared."

"It is understandable that you are like this, after all you just woke up in a totally new environment and, I might add, very strange for you." Said the doctor in an understandable tone. "Now, I need to examine you, to see how you are, all right?" Tommy just nodded and the doctor did the necessary checks. "Now, I assume you would have a question, am I right?"

"Yes, I want to know how the others are doing, the ones on the plane with me, are they okay?"

"I must inform you that, unfortunately, only you and another young man survived the fall and the subsequent fire. He is still unconscious due to a blow to the head, but otherwise he appears to be in perfect health."

Hearing that only someone else on the flight survived was sad for Tommy to hear, he liked those who were with him. "I can see you?" he asked.

"You can see him later. Anything else you want to know?"

"Is everyone here so big?"

"Ha ha ha! No child, most of those who live here are of normal size, only a few are taller, although I should point out that none are as big as Mattie, even the older ones than him. Now the most important thing is that you rest child, so you can recover your strength more quickly. "

15.content:
Awwww yeeeaaaah...

Wind whipped through his hair as Ramone caught the wave in on his surfboard. He could feel the water rushing beneath him, the wind in his hair, the salt on his face. Ramone was tall for his age. He was only seventeen, but he was already about six and a half feet tall. His body was chiseled perfection, thick and beefy with a natural tan. His hair was shaggy brown and his eyes were brown too. His girlfriend adored him and...reckoned he had a cute butt.

As the wave bottomed out, Ramone paddled and then walked, back to shore. He put his surfboard away on the porch of his parents house, and then dragged out his canoe. Ramone loved canoeing. Sometimes he went with friends, other times, alone. Today was an alone day. He just wanted to enjoy the surf and the sun and to relax. He pushed the canoe into the surf and jumped in. Wearing just sandals and boxer-shorts, he could feel the warmth of the sun on his body. Yeah this was good. He picked up one of the oars and started paddling out to sea. Ramone was a machine. His arms powered tirelessly through the waves, digging the paddle deep into the water, left, right, left, right, going faster and faster. Ramone, Ramone, the Metronome.

"Woah..." Ramone said, as the waves started getting larger and larger. Then, he saw the clouds darken.

"Oh crap..." he said. Paddling, he tried to turn the boat around, but already the waves and the wind was getting too strong. Ramone pulled out oarlocks and clipped them to the side of his canoe and then put in the other oar and tried to row back to land, but the waves were now far too powerful! Now it started to rain. Just a drizzle at first, but then a full, monsoonal downpour! In thirty seconds, Ramone was soaking wet! His canoe wasn't easily sunk or capsized however, so he kept on rowing. The skies grew darker until there wasn't any sunlight at all. It was getting really cold now, and Ramone was shivering. This was crazy!

WHUNK!

A huge wave hit the side of the canoe and Ramone was thrown off-balance, he hit the side of his boat and groaned. That freakin' hurt!

Whunk! Whunk! More waves started pounding his canoe. Then, an especially large one gave the boat a full broadside, slamming into the canoe with the force of a speeding car! Ramone was thrown back! His head slammed into the side of the canoe and everything went black...

--- --- --- ---

"Uuuuugggh....Eeeugh!"

Ramone groaned. Where was he!?

Whereever he was, he was lying on sand. Bright sunlight was shining down on him and he noticed his clothes were dry. His brown hair was messy and full of sand. He groaned and tried to scratch as much sand out of his hair as he could.

"Hey you're awake!"
"Yeah..." Ramone said. He looked hazily around, and then got up.

"HOLY JESUS!!" he screamed. He'd turned around to see a collossal figure TOWERING over him, big enough to block out the sun!...or so it seemed.

"Who are you!?" Ramone screamed.

152.content:
"I'm Jake," the massive figure replied calmly. "Who are you?"

"R-Ramone."

"Here, let me help you up." Suddenly, a massive hand encompassed Ramone's entire body, setting him down safely on the ground. "Wow, you're really small."

Ramone stared up at the massive child. He barely came up to the kid's waist. The kid had tree trunk-sized leg muscles, with calves that had to be around 40" in circumference. Jake's shoulders were incredibly wide, casting a huge shadow on the much smaller man below.

Jake's arms were nearly 45" around, it seemed. His traps flared outward and halfway down his back, giving the boy an incredibly intimidating appearance. If it weren't for the sweet, innocent face perched atop the massive body, Ramone would have taken off in the opposite direction, fearing for his life. Not that he would have gotten very far.

"What happened to you?" the child asked, pointing to the wrecked canoe that had washed on shore.

"Oh, rough winds, strong waves. Mother nature can be mean sometimes."

"Oh," Jake replied. "Are you hungry?"

"Sure," Ramone replied. "I can always eat."

"Well, follow me." And with that, Jake bent down and lifted Ramone off the ground again. He placed him over one massive shoulder head, holding him by the legs to keep him in place.

"Hey, hey!" Ramone protested, as the boy started walking. "I can walk, you know."

"It's okay. I don't mind." Ramone tried on a few occasions to pry his body loose, but every time he would struggle, Jake would just apply a bit more pressure to keep him in place. Ramone eventually just gave up.

A few minutes later, Jake arrived at his home. He set Ramone down again and the smaller man stumbled back a few steps.

"I'll be right back," the giant kid said, as he walked toward the kitchen area, his footsteps booming.

"I have to get out of here," Ramone thought to himself, as he quietly made his way towards the door.

But, just as he began to open it, he felt a large hand grab him by the shoulder.

1521.content:
Ramone turned around to see who had their hand on his shoulder. It was a middle-aged man.

"Hi, I'm Bob," the man said, looking down at Ramone. "I'm Jake's father."

Ramone immediately saw that Bob was more than double that of Jake's size. The small man barely came up to Bob's knees. He also had the same musculature and build as his son, too.

"So, what brings you here?" the kindly man asked.

"Jake saw me wash up on the beach, so he brought me here, I guess." Ramone looked around the house. Everything was exactly what one would expect in a modern suburban house. Except that everything was at least three times the normal size. The walls themselves rose nearly 50 feet in the air. Chairs could seat five people of Ramone's size. The TV looked like a movie screen.

"Well, that's Jake," the man replied. "Always trying to help people out." The giant man walked back to his chair and sat down, picking up the newspaper he was reading before.

"Who is it, Bob?" a feminine voice called out from the kitchen. A few seconds later, a woman's frame nearly filled the kitchen doorway. It was apparently Jake's mother. She was as large and as muscular as both Jake and Bob. Her shoulders and arms were phenomenal.

"Oh, I see Jake has a guest. Just make yourself comfortable" She smiled sweetly and went back into the kitchen.

"Where the hell am I?" Ramone asked himself. "It's like these people are the living embodiment of The Incredible Hulk.

Jake then reappeared from the kitchen, a big smile on his face. He was carrying a few sandwiches in one hand. "Come on. I want to show you my room." Without warning, he bent down and slung the tiny man over his massive shoulder again, practically skipping away as he walked.

He entered his bedroom and dropped Ramone down on his bed. Ramone bounced up and down a few times before coming to a stop. "Jake, why do you do that? I can walk, you know?"

"Because it's fun." the child smiled down at him. He handed Ramone a sandwich. The man reluctantly took it and bit into it. It had been hours since he had last eaten. He was starving.

Ramone looked around Jake's room. His bed must have been around 15 feet in length. His toys lying on the floor were nearly as big as he was, and a few surpassed him in height. Everything was gigantic.

"So, what did you want to show me?" the man said, taking another bite from his sandwich.

"Nothing, really. I just wanted to spend some time with you. You want to play?" Ramone nodded his head.

And over the next hour or so, the two played. First with a few action figures, then hide and seek. The man had to admit, it was fun playng with this child, despite his hulking size. Still, at every opportunity he got, Ramone looked for a way to escape.

"Jake! Dinner!" his mother yelled.

"I'm busy playing with Ramone!" the child responded.

"N-No!" Ramone said quickly, grabbing Jake by the hand. "I'm actually getting hungry again."

Jake shrugged, looking down at him. "Okay, then." He then picked Ramone up once more, depositing him only when he got to the dinner table. There was even a detour to the bathroom, where Jake went to relieve himself. All the while, Ramone dangled over Jake's back, shifting a few times when he got uncomfortable. In the back of his mind, Ramone thought the child was doing this to somehow impress him or something.

*****************************

It was nighttime. Jake and Ramone had been in the child's bedroom for the past two hours, the only breaks coming when one of them had to go to the bathroom. Ramone was propped up against the wall, fighting to stay awake. They had been playing ever since dinner was over. The man was exhausted.

"So, then," Jake said, finishing up a story. "The man at the store laughed so hard when dad fell down, he peed his pants!" Jake laughed a boisterous laugh.

Ramone, eyes half-open, gave a complimentary smile. "Jake?" he asked. "Can we please go to bed? I'm exhausted."

Jake sighed, picking his new friend up and depositing him on the bed once more. The child got dressed in his pajamas. When he turned around, Ramone was already asleep.

The child climbed into bed, being careful not to hurt Ramone. In a few minutes, Jake himself was asleep, too.
1521.title: It was Bob, Jake's father

choices: Jake's
Margaret's
15212.content:
Ramone waited a full half hour before trying to escape. He heard Jake's snoring, the bellowing noise nearly causing him to go deaf.

The man slowly made his way out of the bed, dropping down softly on the floor below. (It was about a five foot drop.) He opened the door and made his way towards the living room.

The living room was shrouded in darkness, the only light coming from a lamp in the other room. Ramone made his way to the front door, making sure no one was watching him. He jumped up, grabbing hold of the knob.

"Going somewhere?" the mother asked from behind. Ramone jumped down and turned around. She was sitting on the couch, watching his every move.

"I'm sorry," Ramone said. "It's just that Jake is--"

"Incredibly annoying? Possessive? Yeah, I know." The mother smiled. "Come here," she offered, patting the cushion next to her. Ramone made his way over to the couch, climbing the massive piece of furniture. He sat down next to the massive woman, and looked in awe of her frame.

"Yeah, I had to get out of there," the man continued. "He was...suffocating me."

"It's okay," Margaret replied. "He's always been like that. Jake always treated things he likes that way. It's no reason for you to run away."

"I'm sorry," the man said, lowering his head. "I've just never experienced something like this before, you know? It's shocking, fascinating. Scary."

"What's there to be scared of? We're humans, just like you."

"But you're gigantic," Ramone replied. "I mean, to me, you're like 25 or 30 feet tall. I come up to the waist on Jake, but that's hardly any consolation."

The two sat in silence for a moment. "How did you get so big?" the man asked.

"There was this spring here on the island," the mother began. "We had been stranded here when our cruise ship had been overrun by pirates and the three of us snuck off on a life raft. One day, we come across this spring. So, we all take a drink, because, at that point, we're parched, you know? It had been a few days since he had had an clean water.

"So, we each take a cup and drink from the spring. And when we wake up the next morning, we're...this big." She motions up and down her body with her hand. "And we just decided to make this place our home, since if we were ever able to return to America, we'd be locked up by the government and/or used in experiments."

"What happened to the spring?" Ramone asked.

"Bob went back the next day and destroyed it. He said the water had too much power in it and that if it ever fell into the wrong hands, say, a group of terrorists, or a shipload of pirates, they would be unstoppable."

Ramone shook his head.

"You know, you're kind of cute," the mother said, looking down at him, smiling.

"Thanks."

"Look, I know you think Jake is this big chore or whatever," Margaret said, changing the subject. "But believe me, he's worth the trouble."

Just then, the two could hear thudding footsteps coming down the hallway. "Mom?" Jake asked, standing in the doorway. "Have you seen Ramone?"

She looked down at the man sitting next to her, his eyes going wide. "No, dear," she replied. "Maybe he's sleeping somewhere else. We'll look for him in the morning. Okay, sweetie?"

The child nodded his head and returned to his room. Ramone looked up at Margaret and mouthed the words "Thank you."

She smiled, looking down at him. "Sometimes, we all need a break from Jake." She stood up. "Well, I'm going to bed. You want to sleep here tonight?"

"Yes, please," Ramone replied, glancing back towards Jake's bedroom.

The mother brought in a blanket and an extra pillow. Ramone laid down, watching as Margaret turned and walked away.

The next morning, Ramone woke up to see __________'s face staring back at him.
15212.title: Ramone was only faking; he tries to escape

152121.content:
Ramone slowly opened his eyes, as the sunlight streamed into the living room. He put a hand over his face, to block the sun out for a few more minutes. As time passed, he could feel a presence watching him.

He opened his eyes to find Jake's giant head staring down at him. "Morning, Ramone," he said, smiling. "Ready for breakfast?"

"Only if you don't carry me this time," he replied, a slight grin on his tired face. Ramone sat up on the couch, as he tried to get as awake as possible before putting his feet on the floor.

He walked into the kitchen, Jake following close behind. He sat down and looked at what was being served. Breakfast consisted of a few dozen fish, some fruit picked from somewhere on the island, and a loaf of bread, made from scratch.

After everyone had eaten, Jake practically dragged Ramone outside, anxious to play with his new friend.

"Come on, Jake," the man protested. "Can't I go back to bed for a few more hours?"

"No," the child responded, not slowing down. "It's a beautiful day; we're going to play today."

They stopped roughly in the middle of the island. "So, what do you want to play?" Jake asked.

Ramone thought for a moment, an idea forming. "What about hide and seek?"

"Okay!" the kid said cheerily. "You go hide." Jake then turned around and covered his eyes, as he began counting.

Ramone ran off, hiding behind a cluster of large trees. He didn't really care if he was found or not; he only cared about being "it" in a few minutes so he could try to make it to his canoe and hopefully escape.

"One-hundred!" he heard Jake call out. "Ready or not, here I come!" Ramone could feel the tremors being set off with Jake's every step. As time passed, he could feel the tremors becoming louder and the ground shaking more and more as the child approached.

Off in the distance, Jake could see Ramone's head sticking out from behind the trees. He rushed over, bending a few of the trees over with his bare hands.

"Found you!" Jake said triumphantly. "Okay, your turn." Jake turned and ran off, as Ramone started counting. As soon as Jake was out of sight, Ramone started heading towards the shore, in the hopes that his boat was salvageable.

Halfway there, however, he could hear a rustling in the foliage on either side of him. He stopped, waiting for whatever it was to show itself, but it never showed. Ramone continued walking, and the sound returned, along with a low growl from whatever was following him.

Ramone started getting nervous, looking side to side, in hopes of seeing whichever creature had thoughts of making him into breakfast. Suddenly, it emerged: a pack of hyenas, three in all, circling slowly around him.

They bared their teeth, ready to lunge. Ramone picked up a piece of wood of some kind off the ground, ready to defend himself.

One of the creatures lunged at him and Ramone caught the animals teeth on the piece of wood. The hyena bit down hard, trying to shake the wood from the prey's hands, but it was no use; he let go and walked back over to his pack, ready to strike again.

Without warning, all three hyenas lunged into the air and Ramone knew he had no way of defending against all of them. He closed his eyes, ready to accept his fate.

Just then, Jake appears from behind a large tree. He shoves Ramone out of the way, as the hyenas latch onto him. Their bites cause nothing more than superficial wounds however and the massive child easily plucks them from his body, like someone removing leeches after swimming in leech-infested waters.

Jake removes the animals and tosses them safely, but forcefully enough, into the brush ahead of him. All three slink back into the darkness of the jungle-like island, defeated.

Ramone walks over to his giant protector. "Thank you," he says. "Are you okay?"

"Flesh wounds," the child responds simply, inspecting himself. "I'll be okay." He takes a deep breath. "We should head back home."

1521211.content:
Jake starts walking quickly in the direction of his house, causing Ramone to practically run to keep up.

"Jake! Jake, slow down!" The child didn't comply, ignoring him completely. "Are you mad me or something?"

"What do you think?!" Jake replied, turning around sharply. "You were trying to escape, weren't you?" Ramone just stood there, not answering. The sight of having a 10 foot child angry at him had the teen a little afraid. "Yeah, that's what I thought." He began walking away again, leaving Ramone behind.

"At least let me explain!" he said, running up to Jake again. The boy stopped, turning around, folding his massive arms in front of his chest. He glared down at Ramone.

"Okay," Ramone said. "I know you're mad at me. But, you have to understand, I have a family and friends where I'm from. I even have a girlfriend. Those people probably miss me."

"And you couldn't just ask me to help you? You had to just run off, without even an explanation?!"

"I know, I know," the teen said. "I'm sorry. I shouldn't have done that. Is there anything I can do to make it up to you?"

"Just leave me alone," Jake said, storming off. "I don't care if you leave now. I really don't. If you DO go back to my house, tell mom I'll be back in a few hours."

"Jake wait a minute," Ramone said, running up to him once more. "Just tell me what--"

"I SAID LEAVE ME ALONE!'!" Jake turns around and shoves Ramone, sending him flying into the air, landing about 50 yards away on the shore.

"There!" the child yelled at him, pointing a little to Ramone's right. "There's your stupid boat! Now go!"

Ramone groaned as he looked and saw his canoe lying in the sand a little ways from him. He then saw Jake run and leap into the air, arching high in the sky, before hurdling back to the earth a few miles away. Ramone felt the rumble caused by the giant child when he landed.

He walked over to his canoe to inspect it, his chest sore where he had been shoved, a large welt forming, along with a bruise. Ramone winced as he bent down to look at the damage. Even if he wanted to try to get away, he still had to repair the large hole in the side of his boat.

He started walking, clutching his chest as he walked.

His destination:

15213.content:
Ramone easily slipped off Jake's bed and snuck toward the front door. No one was around, so he quietly opened the door and started walking towards the shore.

In the darkness outside, Ramone was finding it difficult to make it to the other end of the island. He stumbled, tripping over tree stumps and falling into small ditches as he made it to his canoe.

As he approached the shore, the moonlight shining off the surface of the island, his eyes finally adjusted. Ramone started to inspect his canoe, when he heard a low growl coming from the shadows. He turned around, the green eyes of a pair of animals shining off the moonlight.

Ramone worked more quickly, trying to lift his boat off the sand it was embedded in. The animals walked slowly toward him, their sleek bodies sizing up their prey. They were panthers. They hissed and Ramone started shaking.

The animals advanced on him and Ramone took off in the opposite direction, running for his life. He made his way through the island, the leaves from low-lying trees whipping him in the face as he ran. He saw a tree that he could easily climb. roughly 30 feet tall, and began climbing.

He was about halfway up the tree, when he looked down, to see the panthers jumping futilely up at him. They stalked the bottom of the tree, waiting patiently for Ramone to stumble. However, once he made it to the top, he situated himself comfortably in a tree branch, his back resting against the body of the tree.

He looked down to see the panthers, curling up next to the tree, drifting off to sleep, making escape, at least for tonight, impossible. He was stranded in the middle of the island. Probably a few miles away from Jake and his family. Escape, at least for tonight, was impossible. Ramone eventually drifted off to sleep.

***********************************

Ramone was awakened by a series of rumblings off in the distance. "Ramone!" a voice called out, "Ramone! Can you hear me?"

The man, looked over his shoulder, to see both Jake and his mother looking for him, their hulking frames being silhouetted by the morning sunrise. The rumblings Ramone heard were the giant's footsteps.

"Ramone, where are you?" the mother yelled out. The two were making their way slowly towards him. Ramone looked down to see the panthers had run off, probably scared by the giants footsteps.

He tried to move slowly down the tree, but with the tremors caused by Jake and Margaret's footsteps, he had a hard time getting a grip. Suddenly, his foot slipped
and Ramone grasped for the closest branch he could get ahold of. Thankfully, he grabbed it in time, but it also caught the attention of Jake's mother.

The tree shook and a few leaves fell to the ground, not to mention a flock of birds flew away, all thanks to Ramone. "Shit!" he muttered under his breath, as he tried to climb back onto the branch.

He succeeded, but not before a pair of eyes were staring at him. The hulking frame of whoever it was obviously knew Ramone was hiding in the tree.

Who was it?
15213.title: Ramone successfully escapes

choices: He stays with Jake
`He goes to his own bed
He tries to escape
1523.content:
"Are you trying to escape?" Jake asked, looking down at Ramone.

"N-No!" he replied, turning around to see one of Jake's massive hands resting on his shoulder, the other holding a giant plate of food.

"It was just...just..." Ramone continued, trying to find an acceptable excuse. "I was just looking for, um... Okay, I was trying to escape."

"Why?" Jake asked.

"Well, you're a little intimidating. I'm afraid of you."

"I'm not going to hurt you," Jake replies. "Now come on, let's eat." He guides Ramone over to the large table he had in the middle of the room. Ramone sits down in one of the chairs. His feet barely reach the edge of the seat, the chair is so large. Jake puts some food in a plate and hands it to Ramone. He does the same for himself.

"So, why did you really try to run?" Jake asked, taking a bite of his food.

"I don't know, really."

"Well, it wouldn't be the first time somebody ran away from me," the boy explains. "Eventually, everyone succeeds in getting away from me."

"What happens to the people that do?" Ramone asked.

"Half of them are killed by the wild animals that roam this island. They usually leave at night, so I can't stop them. A few days later, I find their bodies. Or what's left of them, anyway." Ramone gulped.

"And for the few that DO successfully escape, well, I guess they find their way home or crashed on another island or something. I don't really care." Jake took another bite of food, obviously irritated.

"Why are you so big?" Ramone asked.

"It's the water here," the boy explained. "When me and my family first arrived here, I drank a little bit of it and over the next month or so, I grew into my current size."

"Did your parents have any of the water?"

"Of course," Jake replied. "But my dad later found out, that it only affects people that haven't gone through puberty yet."

"Where are your parents?" Ramone asked.

Jake paused. "They're dead. We had been here for a few months and we had all gone to sleep for the night. Then, my dad hears a noise outside and he goes to find out what it is. Suddenly, one of the animals tackles him to the ground and starts attacking him. By the time I got outside, he was dead. My mom died of food poisoning a few months after that."

"I'm sorry."

"It was two years ago," Jake replies. "It's okay."

"You've been here alone for the past two years?!" Ramone says in disbelief.

"Well, I've had a few pets here on the island, but that's about it."

The two sat in silence for a few minutes, eating their food.

"I'm sorry I tried to run," Ramone apologized.

"I'm sorry I picked you up earlier," Jake followed. "It's just been so long since I've seen another human. I was just excited. I'm sorry."

Ramone looked around the house he was in. It looked pretty good, considering it was handmade. It was roughly made like a log cabin, with Jake probably ripping the trees out of the ground with his bare hands and his dad, at the time, keeping the trees together with...mud, or something.

There were various pieces of furniture around the house: a couch in the corner, a few chairs dotting the room. A few tables. Obviously, there wasn't a TV or a computer, but all in all, it wasn't half bad.

***************************************

It was nighttime. The food had long been eaten and Jake and Ramone had whittled the past few hours away by talking.

"You ready for bed?" Jake asked. Ramone nodded. Jake led his guest back into the sleeping quarters.

"Now, there is a guest bedroom here," the child said, pointing to one room. "But, well...would you mind sleeping in my bed for tonight?"

Ramone smiled. "Sure."

"The kid's just lonely," Ramone thought to himself.

The two walked into Jake's room and laid down on the bed.

"Good night," Jake said.

"Good night," Ramone replied.

What does Ramone do during the night?"
1523.title: It was Jake

choices: Hunt/fish
Jake shows Ramone around the island
15232.content:
Ramone waited until the massive child drifted off to sleep. He then very carefully got out of bed and walked toward the door. He stopped in the doorway, looking back at Jake.

He was resting quietly, a small snore escaping his nose every few seconds or so. "This would be the perfect time to escape," Ramone thought to himself. "I could walk to the shore, fix up my canoe and be gone by sunrise."

"But,then again," he continued. "Jake is all alone here. He's been without human contact for two whole years. He needs a father figure. I guess, for now, that has to be me. Besides, he saved my life. I owe him that much, at least."

Ramone walked into the guest bedroom, lying down on the humongous bed and eventually fell asleep.

**********************************

He was awoken the next morning by Jake, who had walked into the bedroom and picked Ramone up by one of his legs, suspending him upside down.

"Good morning, Ramone," Jake greeted his guest, smiling, as he brought his smaller body up to Jake's much larger face.

"Good morning, Jake," the teen responded groggily, as he rubbed his eyes, adjusting to the sunlight streaming in. "Mind telling me why I'm hanging upside down?"

"Just wanted to tell you that breakfast is ready." He placed Ramone back down on the bed, perhaps a bit too hard. Jake had already left the room by the time Ramone rolled over, leaving him alone in the bedroom. He rubbed his eyes for a moment, then got up and walked into the kitchen.

When he got there, Jake already had the food out. There was a big pile of fish on one plate, a pile of fruit on another and something that looked like bread in another plate. Also, there was a pitcher of what appeared to be freshly squeezed orange juice on the table.

As Ramone sat down, Jake grabbed a big handful of fish and popped them into his mouth. The teen was handed a plate and grabbed a few fish, chewing small bites. He watched as Jake reached for the fruit, taking about half of the pile and ate them in one gulp.

"So, how did you get this food, Jake?" Ramone asked, taking another bite of his food.

"I hunt for fish every morning, plus I have a garden not far from here, where I grow the fruit." He poured some of the OJ out into a large glass and took a few sips, as he reached for the bread.

"And sometimes, I'll hunt for an animal, but it takes a lot of them to satisfy me. Plus, there are more fish around here than wild animals."

Ramone nodded, as he reached for the fruit and bread.

"With a body this big, it takes a lot of food to keep me full," Jake added.

"You know," the teen said. "This is probably all that I can eat, so you can have the rest."

"Oh, thanks," the child replied, as he grabbed the fish plate and stuffed the rest into his mouth. He followed that by finishing off the fruit, then eating the rest of the bread.

Ramone watched the young boy eat his food in amazement.

"So, do we have any plans for today?"

"Well," Jake replied, swallowing the food in his mouth. "I have to pull up more fruit and maybe catch a few animals for lunch. I could show you around the island, too."

"That'd be nice," Ramone replied, finishing off his breakfast.

"You ready to go?" the young boy asked, standing up.

"Yeah."

What do they do?
15232.title: `He goes to his own bed

choices: They reach the shore without any more distractions
Something else happens
152321.content:
Jake walked into another room, grabbing a few large fishing nets he had made himself some time ago. He then reentered the living room, where Ramone waited patiently by the door.

"Ready to go?" he asked Ramone, opening the front door.

"Yeah. I guess we're fishing, huh?" He looked up at the nets. To Jake, they were probably normal sized, but to Ramone, they looked like they belonged on the side of a fishing boat. The kid could probably catch a few hundred fish a day with those things. Jake slung the nets over his shoulders as the two headed out.

They walked deeper into the island, as the giant child took Ramone on a little sightseeing tour. "And there's where the spring used to be," he said, pointing towards a small rocky formation. "The water that turned me this big used to flow down those rocks, before it just dried up one day."

They walked about half a mile more, before they came to the base of a cliff. "And at the top of this cliff, that's where I saw your canoe out in the ocean."

"You did?"

"Yeah," Jake continued. "In fact, I can see everything that goes on on this island from the top of that cliff. Plus, it's a good place to go if I want to get away from everything else."

Jake's stomach growled. The boy grabbed it, trying to make it stop. "I'd better eat something soon. I'm getting hungry again."

They continued walking, trying to make it to the shore, so they could fish, when they both saw leaves rustling up ahead.

"Stay here," Jake said, placing a huge arm across Ramone's body. "I'd better take care of this." The child walked quietly towards the noise, ready to fight, if necessary. He pulled back a few tree branches, to find a few hyenas. They had been following the two for the past 15 minutes, just waiting for the perfect opportunity to strike.

There were three of them, all of them baring their teeth at Jake. The animals leapt into the air, each one of them latching onto the boy. One bit into Jake's upper thigh, another his midsection and the final one, bit down hard on his forearm. Ramone just stood there, watching the fight take place.

Jake took his massive thumb and forefinger and grabbed the one hyena that was latched onto his forearm, squeezing his neck in one swift motion, killing him. He broke the animal's neck, his lifeless body falling helplessly to the ground. He did the same to the other two hyenas, pulling them off of his body first.

The child looked down at the creatures that laid at his feet. He picked one of them up, observing it. "Want some?" he offered to Ramone, extending his hand.

"Do I want some?!" the teen replied. "Jake, you're not going to eat that animal raw, are you?"

"I've done it before. I do whatever I have to do to survive."

"No, go ahead." Ramone watched over the next several minutes, as the child ate every carcass, stripping all the meat off the bones before moving on to the next one.

In less than five minutes he was done, wiping the excess blood from his chin. He grabbed a handful of fruit from a tree overhead, tossing the items into his mouth, to wash it all down.

"Okay, I'm ready," Jake said afterward, walking back over to Ramone. The teen stared up at the child, amazed that someone could go through three dead hyenas that fast, but also a little bit disgusted that he had eaten them raw in the first place.

"What?" Jake asked, noticing the look on Ramone's face.

"N-nothing," he replied, trying to shake the image he had just seen from his mind. "Just forget it."

"All right, then. I guess it's on to the shore to do some fishing." He grabbed the fishing nets from the ground and slung them back over his shoulder again, as the two started walking once more.
152321.title: Hunt/Fish

choices: ".... my Prince, he'll know what to do with you."
"... my little brother, he'll enjoy having such a cute toy like you."
"... my home, I could use a little help to clean my fishes."
154.content:
The giant didn't seem older than Ramone but was almost three times taller than him and had shaggy brown hair and green eyes; he was dressed in blue shorts and white tank top, and his bulging muscles were clearly visible under the tanned skin.... In fact, the young titan was holding a huge basket, full of fishes, in one hand, like if it was as light as a feather! Ramone's eyes widened in shock at the sight of such a body, and imagining how much power those muscles certainly possessed, he couldn't prevent himself from feeling little and powerless, a feeling he had never experienced since when he reached adulthood... the stranded teen cringed in fear.

The behemot looked down to Ramone with a smirk, amused at the smaller guy's fear. "I'm Largo." he introduced himself. "And who're you, little guy?"

Ramone felt rather outraged at being called that way, but realized that was unavoidable, with such a huge person. Trying to stay calm, he uttered "Ramone."

Largo smiled. "Nice to meet you, Ramone. Where do you come from? I never saw such a small person before..."

Ramone started to explain that he had been shipwrecked there and came from America, but the giant seemed puzzled.
"Wait, little one." Largo said, scratching his head. "I don't know what you're talking about... I'd better to bring you to..."
154.title: Largo the Great Fisher Giant

choices: To keep him as a pet
To give him back to you; do with him as you see fit
Release him into the wild
1541.content:
"I'd better bring you to my Prince. He'll know what to do with you." He grabbed Ramone off the ground and started walking, making his way through the foliage of his island home.

A little while later, Largo entered the palace grounds. The place was immaculate, decorated with gold and silver, with large paintings hanging on the wall. The windows had curtains made of the finest silk hanging from them.

Largo approached the royal court. "I wish to speak with the Prince, please," he said to the guard at the door. The guard went inside for a moment,before returning a few moments later, gesturing for the two to enter. The guard then went back to his post, outside the door.

Largo walked down a long hallway, before stopping at the base of a huge throne. Soon, a large, equally muscular young man sat down in the chair. "You may approach," the man said.

Largo walked a little closer, explaining what he had found that morning. He extended his arms, showing the Prince the tiny man.

"Bring him closer," the Prince said, as Largo brought Ramone to him. The Prince held him in his hands,contemplating what to do about this discovery.

"Where are you from, tiny man?" he asked.

"America," Ramone replied.

"America?" the Prince said, intrigued. "I've heard of that place before."

"So, what are you going to do with him?" Largo asked.

"I've decided..."
1541.title: ".... my Prince, he'll know what to do ...

choices: "... my parents."
"... my younger brothers."
15412.content:
Ramone shivered, while he was handed back to Largo, who quickly bowed to his Prince and walked away. While they came out of the palace, the smaller teen looked up to the giant, and said in a worried tone: "Hey, largo, what do you plan

to do with me? I... I need to go home to my parents, they must be worried..."

"I'm sorry for you, little one." Largo replied earnestly. "But I have no idea about how to send you back home. I never heard of that island called America!"
Ramone, frustrated,
opened his mouth to explain that America was a continent and not an island, but Largo kept speaking. "Don't worry, I'm going to keep you at my place." He smiled down. "We're going to treat you well."

"We?" the tiny guy said. "Do you have family?"

"Yeah!" the giant nodded. "I live with..."
15412.title: Life with Largo

choices: The boy plays with Ramone like a toy
The boy calls a few friends over, showing off his new toy
The boy makes a home for his new toy
1542.content:
"I'd better bring you to my little brother. He'll enjoy having such a cute toy like you." At the sound of those words, Ramone turned and ran as fast as he could, a futile gesture, given the size of the giant before him.

"Hey, where are you going, little guy?" Largo asked, bending down and picking the smaller teenager up. Grabbing him by the waist, Largo brought Ramone up to his face. "Yeah. I believe you'll make a fine toy for my brother.

"Please," Ramone pleaded. "I'm not a toy; I'm a human being."

"You sure look like one," Largo responded. "Plus, you weigh about the same as one of my brother's toys." He paused a moment, contemplating. "Yep. It' official: You're gonna be a toy." He gripped Ramone a little tighter as he started walking towards his home, his basketful of fish easily held against his hip as he walked.

Ramone watched as they approached Largo's house. Actually, after looking around, it was more of a burgeoning community. Averaged-sized homes dotted the area, with every other home lined with a white-picket fence. Various animals, each giant to little Ramone, sat or played in their respective yards, as children as large, if not larger, than Largo, played baseball in the middle of the street. There were no adults that Ramone could see, only giant, muscular children playing or reading a book or doing something else to occupy their time. It was just like "Lord of the Flies."

...You know, if the characters in "Lord of the Flies" had the resources to develop their own functional cul-de-sec neighborhood.

"Here we are," Largo said, as he opened the front door of his house. He walked in the kitchen and placed the fish on the counter. "Tommy! I got somthing for you!" Largo yelled to his brother upstairs.

A few seconds later, Ramone could hear a loud rumbling coming from one of the rooms upstairs. Someone was running down the stairs, everything in the house seeming to shake as he ran. Soon, a figure emerged, walking up to Largo.

"Yeah, what is it,Largo?" the younger child asked.

"I found this lying on the shore." He extended his hand and Ramone looked up at the boy. He had to be around 13 or so. He was roughly the same size as Largo, give or take five feet or so. Well, five feet to Ramone, just a couple of inches to the two boys. He was wearing a Gap t-shirt, the fabric stretched to its limit. The shirt hid the wide and dense musculature of the kid's shoulders. His chest jutted outward, hiding a pair of pectorals that would put any professional bodybuilder to shame. His arms were massive, though, thanks to the shirt, only a small portion was visible. Still, thick forearm muscles, roughly the same size as Lee Priest's, snaked up to his wrist.

"Cool!" the boy said, plucking the small teen from his older brother. "Who is he?"

"Just some guy who washed up on shore today, I guess. I decided you can have him."

The boy smiled, as he walked back to his room, looking down at his new toy, smiling. "You and me are going to have o much fun."

Ramone froze in fear, not knowing what was in store for him.
1542.title: "... my little brother, he'll enjoy hav...

choices: He successfully sends it out
Tommy comes back and sees the e-mail
15423.content:
Tommy walked into his room and placed Ramone on his bed. He opened his closet door, trying to pull something out, hidden in the back. A few moments later, after fishing through a few fallen shirts and pants, the boy brought out several pieces of a hamster cage, placing it in front of his bed and trying to put it all together.

"So, Tommy," Ramone said,making conversation. "You're pretty big for a kid your age."

"Yeah, I know," the boy replied, taking it as a compliment. "Though, lucky for me, my generation is going to be even bigger than Largo's."

Ramone gulped, trying to imagine Tommy even bigger than his brother one day. "That's...good," he said slowly, the realization sinking in.

Tommy wiped off the few remaining pieces of gunk on the side of the cage, then placed it on the bed. It rose about 25 feet into the air, to Ramone anyway, glistening like an orange, transparent dollhouse. "I guess hamsters here are as big as horses," Ramone mused to himself.

"Well, here you go," the kid said, motioning for Ramone to go inside.

"Actually, can I stay out for a while?" the man asked. "I have a little problem with enclosed spaces."

"Oh, okay," Tommy said, putting the hamster cage back on the floor. "I didn't want you to go to sleep yet, anyway." He picked Ramone up and walked over to his computer desk. He sat down, turning the computer on. Ramone watched as the Microsoft logo came on, followed by the chime.

The kid then went to a half dozen websites in the next half-hour, while Ramone sat patiently on the desk, next to the mouse pad. "You wanna check your e-mail?" Tommy asked. "I'm going to go to a friend's house."

"Sure," Ramone answered, walking over to the computer. The kid soon left, leaving him alone in the room.

He started typing an e-mail out, sending it to as many people as he could think of, hoping someone could rescue him...
15423.title: The boy makes a home for his new toy

choices: A bad treatment.
A good treatment.
Taken away by a different giant.
1543.content:
"What?" Ramone gasped nervously, looking up at the imposing figure above him. "Hey wait, wait!" he protested, "I'm not a servant, I'm just a citizen who has just been shipwrecked here and..."

".... and you need help." Largo concluded. "That's what I'm offering: food, shelter and..." he smirked, "Protection for such a small guy like you. But it's just fair that you reward me somehow, don't you think?"

Ramone mused for a moment, then hesitantly said "Well, I suppose so, but-"

"Fine, I'm glad youl ike this arrangement!" Largo said quickly, snatching the smaller man under one arm. "Then let's go home. You'll enjoy helping me, you see."

Ramone, sighing, hoped the giant boy was right about that.
1543.title: Largo's new helper

choices: Eating lunch.
Something happens.
15432.content:
Largo began walking at a fast pace, causing poor Ramone to be jostled, while being hed in the mighty grip. The giant teen headed toward a thick forest that started not afar from the shore, and the smaller man found himself surrounded by immensely tall trees, it looked like a Canadian forest.... only on a larger scale!

After a while, they arrived to a wooden hut; Largo opened the heavy door with a kick and went inside, placing Ramone on the floor. The smaller guy, still dizzy, wobbled and would've fallen down, if a huge hand hadn't quickly seized his shoulder to keep him standing. "Ahem, sorry." said Largo, while putting down his basket. "I should've realized that carrying you could be a bit uncomfortable to you."

"D-Don't worry." replied Ramone, who felt that the giant was actually symphatetic.... Besides, he didn't want to get on his colossal host's bad side.

The small dude looked around. The room had not a lot of furniture, just a table, a bench and a cupboard, all made of wood of course; there was a stone fireplace and a ladder leading to the upper floor.

"You have a nice house." Ramone said. "Do you live here alone?"

"Yeah." Largo nodded with a sad tone. "My parents both died two years ago... They're buried in the backyard."

"I'm sorry, I didn't mean to upset you." Ramone apologized.

The huge teen shrugged. "No problem, I got used to that." Meanwhile, he was rummaging in the cupboard, and walked back to his tiny guest, handing him a knife. The metal object seemed small in the behemot's hand, but when Ramone grabbed it, he realized it was bigger than a butcher knife. Largo asked: "Do you have any experience at cleaning fish?"

Ramone nodded. "Sure, I use to fish a lot."

"Good." the giant said, and placed two bowls on the floor, beside the basket. "Put the cleaned stuff in the bowl on the right, and the rubbish in the left one." he said in a calm yet commanding voice, that made Ramone feel REALLY tiny and helpless for a moment. But then, the fisher teen smiled, adding: "While you work, I'll prepare lunch. I hope you like vegetable soup."

Sitting cross-legged beside the basket and the bowls, Ramone said: "It's perfectly fine. Thanks, Largo."

Largo smiled, and went to the cupboard to pick up some vegetables.
15432.title: Setting in

info.brief_description: You're stranded and rescued by giant muscular boys who take you in! This is your story...
info.description:
In this story, the protagonist is stranded on an island, in the desert, in the jungle, or on an unknown planet, and is rescued and/or found by a giant, muscular boy. This benevolent boy takes the lost person to his home, and decides to take care of him from that point forward. Escape becomes impossible, although the protagonist does try it. After all, he is on an island, in the desert, on a planet or in the jungle. But the boys are too big, too fast, and too strong. Also, the protagonist might get in trouble, or get attacked by other creatures, and then the muscle boys will come to his rescue... again!

The protagonist may be another teen or an adult. The giant muscle boys are always bigger and stronger than the protagonist, but they don't necessarily need to be older. In fact, it would be fun if most of the giant boys were younger. That way, the protagonist could end up becoming an instructor and a teacher further in the story.

The giant boys can be farmers, hunters, or fishermen. They may or may not have parents living with them. The point is, they are all bigger and stronger than the protagonist. The protagonist may become a servant or assistant to the boy, who has rescued him at first.

What happens to the person, when he is found by a group or tribe of giant muscle boys? How does he fit in? How will he adopt? How will he be treated? What happens, when he tries to escape? Usually, the protagonist will grow very close to one muscle boy in particular, and it would be fun to see that friendship grow between a normal-sized human being and a giant 12ft muscle boy.

Story Rules and Requirement:
NO one-line chapters... they will get deleted right away!
NO sex between minors.
GP's awarded for chapters of 500 words or longer which follow the story arc and are well written.
